name: Runes & Desolation: Wizard 26 / Fighter 6 / Divine Champion 8
author: grizzled_dwarflord

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
My apologies if this already exists somewhere.  Mods feel free to remove if so.  I've been dusting off a lot of old builds that have just been sitting in my Vault waiting to storm the gates.

What's not to love about an undispellable Dwarf Wizard who can practices a scorched earth policy with devastating crit?

Runes & Desolation
 
Classes: Wizard 26 / Fighter 6 / Divine Champion 8
Playable: 1-40 PvE Low to Mid Magic
Alignment: Any Non-Evil
Race: Dwarf (or Human (Elf or Half-elf are compatible as well))
 
Statistics
Str: 16 (30)
Int: 16 (19)
Wis: 8
Dex: 8
Con: 18
Chr: 6

Combat Vitals
AB: 40

Hit Points: 404
Buffed Attack Schedule: 51/46/41/36/51
Hasted True Strike Attack Schedule: 66/61/56/51/66
Base Damage: 1d12+21 (19-20 x3) crit range
Buffed Damage: 1d12+35 +14 Fire (17-20 x3)

Saving Throws
Fortitude: 33 (44 vs spells)
Will: 26 (37 vs spells)

Feel Free to divide your skills up any way you see fit, just make sure to max Concentration & Spellcraft at the appropriate level-ups.
 
Special Powers:
Epic Warding
Devastating Critical
Knockdown
Undispellable Buffs (eventually)
Doesn’t rely on AC – instead uses Stilled or Extended Damage Shields against high AB hitters
Can Still all Damage shields and IGMS
High Enough Spell Penetration to pierce the highest Standard Toolset SR (still won’t penetrate pure Monks, that’s what damage shields and Dev Crit are for).
 
Related Builds: Abjurant Champion.  Great minds think alike.  The main differences between these two is the Abjurant is an Auto Still hybrid that still focuses in a spell school.  This build goes in a more melee direction by achieving higher AB and grabbing Dev Crit.
Mithdrates' Magical Marauder:  Same idea, but he opted for Auto Stills as well.  Really the Abjurant Champion is an improved version of the Magical Marauder.
 
Builder’s Commentary:
I’ve been playing these style of builds for years, but usually they involved a Fighter/Wizard/WM hybrid that still achieved essentially the same split.  What I find liking about this particular brand of Spellswords is that there are a variety of playstyles involved throughout the career of the build.  In the early stages you start as a pure Wizard and play as one, and then you transition to the fighter type who can self buff and create utility wands to support his fledgling melee career.  It’s almost like playing different characters as you develop.  You have to be flexible, and know that you have many ways to skin a cat.
 
He is not a DC Wizard and he makes no apologies for it.  All 3 Spell Penetration feats are taken just for insurance against those fiends and celestials that pop up from time to time.

As you develop into the Epic Levels, you become more of an arcane hybrid:  one can wade into melee decked out in Full Plate and fiery keened Great Axe, fully buffed with the entire retinue of Wizardard defenses, Epic Weapon specialization and creating desolation with Devastating Critical.  He has enough Hit Points that he can take a hit, and if it gets too hot he can turn on Death Armor/Elemental Shield/Acid Sheath, and then fling Time Stops about and unleash a barrage of Stilled Ikes Yikes.
 
The classes are very friendly to 4 races – Dwarven, Elven, Human, Gnome or Half-elf with no xp penalty.  In fact, one might be able to go elf and opt for the 16 or 18 dex, and then rely on Elven Chain and Empowered Cats Grace Buffs.  Human is good for the extra feat and skill points, and I would suggest either Improved Knockdown or Skill Focus: Concentration.
 
One is not limited to the Great Axe, but could easily go Halberd (for 2 damage types and still keenable), or Greatsword for a greater threat range. 
 
Craft Wand, Knockdown and Empower and Extend Spell are chosen for added flexibility and playstyle.  While he is just at home in full plate, he could be equally at home in just robes for a different playstyle.  Saving Throws are very competitive, especially given the +10 he receives in Spellcraft and Dwarven Bonuses.  In a build such as this, one can drop Blindfighting for Expertise or Improved Knockdown.

One may ask, "Why Fighter6/CoT8 and not Ftr 4/CoT10?" The answer is quite simple -- to optimize epic feat acquisition.  By ending pre-epic with Fighter5/CoT7, I ensure 3 epic bonus feats that are staged for optimal dev crit acquisition.  Going the 4/10 route leaves you with Ftr4/CoT8 in pre-epic with only one feat coming in Epic.
 
Tips for Game Play:  a bit of a strip tease involved before you rush off.  Take off armor and cast all your long term buffs, extended or otherwise.  Keep handy Wands of Invis, Improved Invis, Stoneskin, Prot. From Elements, and various Summoning Wands, and Wand of Lesser Breach.  These are handy in the event you get dispelled.  At Level 7 craft your first Wand of ILMS (it’s crafted at 11th caster power which is uber when you are Level 7.
 
Use Breaches to strip enemy casters of their protection shields and damage shields.  Also, don’t forget
 
 
Weaknesses:  You’re not a true Wizard.  You are subject to dispelling for most of your career.  The more Wizard levels you take, the more you can mitigate it.  It’s not until you reach Level 25 Wizard that you become truly undispellable—except for Mords and Breaches.  Those are still going to get you, but they get everybody.

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
An option for netting a higher discipline would be to adjust your level build to 24 Wizard (lowest for undispellable) and increase your Fighter to 8 or COT to 10 netting the same number of feats but extra HP and Discipline. Also, I applaud not taking EMA, I can never seem to commit to not taking it :)

The only cost to this that I can see is your spell penetration drops to 30 + 1d20, increasing your failure rate on the standard 32 SR to 10%
